Counsel:  [*1] For Dura Automotive Systems, Inc., et al., aka Dura Automotive Holdings, Inc., aka MC Holding
                  Corp., Debtor: Daniel J. DeFranceschi, Paul Noble Heath, Richards, Layton & Finger, Wilmington, DE USA; Jason
                  M. Madron, Mark A. Kurtz, Richards, Layton & Finger, P.A., Wilmington, DE; Jason M. Madron, Richards, Layton &
                  Finger, LLP, Wilmington, DE; Judy A. O'Neill, Foley & Lardner LLP, Detroit, MI.
                  For OFFICIAL COMMITTEE OF UNSECURED CREDITORS, Creditor Committee: Edmon L. Morton, Erin
                  Edwards, M. Blake Cleary, Young, Conaway, Stargatt & Taylor, Wilmington, DE, USA.
Judges:  Hon. Kevin J. Carey, UNITED STATES BANKCRUPTCY JUDGE.
Opinion by: Kevin J. Carey

Counsel: Kirkland & Ellis LLP, 200 East Randolph Drive, Chicago, Illinois 60601-6636, Fax:
                  312-861-2200,
                  Attn:
                  Marc
                  Kieselstein,
                  P.C.
                  (mkieselstein@kirkland.com),
                  Roger
                  J.
                  Higgins
                  (rhiggins@kirkland.com), Michael G. Timmers, P.C. (mtimmers@kirkland.com), and Ryan B. Bennett
                  (rbennett@kirkland.com).
                  
                  
                  The Selling Debtors further reserve the right, in their reasonable business judgment, at any time after the Bid
                  Deadline and prior to the conclusion  [*292] of the Auction, to invite parties that have not previously submitted
                  written offers to do so such that they may be considered pursuant to the procedures set forth herein.
                  The Selling Debtors shall provide counsel to the Creditors' Committee, Second Lien Group and DIP Lenders with
                  copies of bids, and a list of parties submitting bids, as soon as is reasonably practicable after the Bid Deadline.
                  7. Determination of Qualifying Bids.
                  The Selling Debtors shall, by no later than 5:00 p.m. (prevailing eastern time), August 10, 2007 (the "Bid
                  Determination Deadline"):
                  (a) determine in their reasonable business judgment whether a written offer is a Qualifying Bid;
                  (b) notify each party submitting a written offer whether that written offer is a Qualifying Bid; and
                  (c) provide copies of each Qualifying Bidders' APA to the Stalking Horse Bidder and all Qualifying Bidders.
                  The Selling Debtors shall consult with the Creditors' Committee regarding their determination of Qualifying Bidders.
                  The Selling Debtors will provide to counsel for the Creditors' Committee, Second Lien Group and DIP Lenders the
                  list of Qualifying Bidders as soon as is reasonably practicable after the Bid Determination Deadline.
                  The  [*293] Selling Debtors reserve the right, at any time after the Bid Deadline and prior to the commencement of
                  the Auction, to request parties submitting written offers that were determined not to be Qualifying Bids to amend
                  their written offers such that those amended written offers may be considered as Qualifying Bids. The Selling
                  Debtors will consult with the Creditors' Committee regarding any such requests.
                  8. Auction Procedures.
                  In the event that the Selling Debtors receive one or more Qualifying Bids, the Auction shall take place at 10:00 a.m.
                  (prevailing eastern time), August 14, 2007, at the offices of Kirkland & Ellis LLP, Citigroup Center, 153 East 53rd
                  Street, New York, New York 10022, or at any such other place, date and time as may be designated in writing by
                  the Selling Debtors. Subject to § 15 hereof, the Auction shall be governed by the following procedures:
                  (a) the Stalking Horse Bidder and each Qualifying Bidder shall appear in person or by telephone, or through a
                  duly authorized representative;
                  (b) the Stalking Horse Bidder and each Qualifying Bidder shall be required to confirm that it has not engaged in
                  any collusion with respect to the bidding or the sale (except for joint  [*294] bidding arrangements disclosed to
                  the Selling Debtors pursuant to § 5(n));
                  (c) only the Stalking Horse Bidder and Qualifying Bidders shall be entitled to submit bids;
                  (d) bidding shall commence at the amount of the highest Qualifying Bid submitted prior to the Auction;
                  (e) the Selling Debtors reserve the right to determine, in their reasonable business judgment, whether a bid
                  constitutes a higher and better offer than previous bids, based upon factors including, but not limited to, the
                  amount of the purchase price, the form of consideration being offered, the likelihood of the bidder's ability to
                  close a transaction and the timing thereof, the number, type and nature of any changes to the APA requested,
                  and the net benefit to the Selling Debtors' estates;
                  (f) bids must be at least $ 750,000 (the "Auction Bid Increment") higher than the outstanding highest bid
                  (though, as discussed in § 15 hereof, the Selling Debtors retain the right to modify, in their business judgment,
                  the bid increment during the Auction); provided however, that any further bid made by the Stalking Horse
                  Bidder shall include a credit (or Purchase Price reduction) equal to the Breakup Fee plus the Maximum
                  Expense Reimbursement  [*295] (the sum of which is the "Credit Bid Amount"), such that any such bid by the
                  Stalking Horse shall result in an increase in value to the Selling Debtors equal to the Auction Bid Increment. 3
                  3 For example, if a Qualifying Bidder bids $ 200,000,000, the Stalking Horse may then bid $ 200,750,000, which includes the
                  Credit Bid Amount, and which will result in an increase in value to the Selling Debtors equal to the Auction Bid Increment.
                  
                  
                  This same Credit Bid Amount shall reduce the Purchase Price in the event that the Stalking Horse Bidder is the
                  Prevailing Bidder;
                  (g) the Stalking Horse Bidder and Qualifying Bidders may make additional modifications to the Stalking Horse
                  APA, APA or Modified APA, as applicable, during the Auction, provided, however, that any such modifications,
                  on an aggregate basis, shall not be less favorable to the Selling Debtors as determined by the Selling Debtors
                  in their reasonable business judgment;
                  (h) the Selling Debtors intend to continue the Auction until there is only one bid that, in their reasonable
                  business judgment, is the highest or best offer, as the case may be (the "Prevailing Bid"--the bidder submitting
                  such Prevailing Bid, the "Prevailing Bidder," shall have such rights and responsibilities as set forth in the
                  applicable APA or Modified APA); provided that the Debtors will consult with the Creditors' Committee
                  regarding the selection of the Prevailing Bidder;
                  (i) the Selling Debtors may, at  [*296] any time prior to the commencement of the Sale Hearing (defined below),
                  continue the Auction from time to time, adjourn the Auction, and re-open the Auction; and
                  (j) the Stalking Horse Bidder and each Qualifying Bidder participating in the Auction shall be deemed to have
                  consented to the core jurisdiction of the Bankruptcy Court.
                  9. No Qualifying Bids.
                  If no Qualifying Bid is submitted by the Bid Deadline, the Selling Debtors may, but are not required, in their
                  reasonable business judgment, cancel the Auction and accept the Stalking Horse Bid (in which case, the Prevailing
                  Bid shall be the Stalking Horse Bid, and the Prevailing Bidder shall be the Stalking Horse Bidder). Prior to
                  announcing any such cancellation, the Selling Debtors shall consult with the Creditors' Committee regarding that
                  cancellation.
                  10. Announcement of Prevailing Bidder and Execution of Agreements.
                  The Selling Debtors reserve the right to announce the identity of the Prevailing  [*297] Bidder at any time prior to
                  the commencement of the Sale Hearing. Within one (1) calendar day after the announcement of the identity of the
                  Prevailing Bidder by the Selling Debtors, the Prevailing Bidder shall complete and execute all agreements,
                  contracts, instruments or other documents evidencing and containing the terms and conditions upon which the
                  Prevailing Bid was made.
                  11. Selling Debtors' Acceptance of Prevailing Bid Subject to Bankruptcy Court Approval.
                  The Prevailing Bid will be subject to approval by the Bankruptcy Court at the Sale Hearing. The Selling Debtors
                  shall be deemed to have accepted the Prevailing Bid only when the Prevailing Bid has been approved by the
                  Bankruptcy Court. The Selling Debtors shall use reasonable efforts to obtain Bankruptcy Court approval of the
                  Prevailing Bid in the form of the sale order attached as Exhibit I to the APA (the "Sale Order").
                  12. Sale Hearing.
                  A hearing (the "Sale Hearing") will be held to approve the sale of the Sale Assets to the Prevailing Bidder before the
                  Honorable Kevin J. Carey in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of Delaware, 824 North Market
                  Street, 5th Floor, Wilmington, Delaware 19801, at 1:30 p.m. (prevailing  [*298] eastern time), August 15, 2007, at
                  such time thereafter as counsel may be heard, or at such other time as the Bankruptcy Court may determine. The
                  Sale Hearing may be adjourned from time to time without further notice to creditors or parties-in-interest other than
                  by announcement of the adjournment in open court on the date scheduled for the Sale Hearing. The Prevailing
                  Bidder and Backup Bidder (defined below), if any, should be represented by counsel at the Sale Hearing.
                  13. Consummation of the Purchase.
                  (a) Closing Deadline.
                  
                  
                  The Prevailing Bidder shall, subject to the terms and conditions set forth in the Prevailing Bidder's APA,
                  consummate the sale transaction contemplated by the Prevailing Bid (the "Purchase") on or before the Closing
                  Deadline (defined in § 5(d) above). Consistent with APA § 8.4, the Prevailing Bidder and the Selling Debtors shall
                  each use their commercially reasonable best efforts to: (i) take all actions necessary or appropriate to consummate
                  the transactions contemplated by the APA and (ii) cause the fulfillment at the earliest practicable date of all of the
                  conditions to their respective obligations to consummate the transactions contemplated by this Agreement.
                  [*299] The Selling Debtors and Prevailing Bidder (in consultation with the Creditors' Committee) may agree to
                  extend the Closing Deadline from time to time in their reasonable business judgment.
                  If the Prevailing Bidder's APA is terminated in accordance with the terms thereof, the Selling Debtors may, in their
                  reasonable business judgment, close the Backup Purchase with the Backup Bidder pursuant to § 13(b), and the
                  Selling Debtors reserve all of their rights under the APA to obtain damages from the Prevailing Bidder.
                  (b) Backup Purchase.
                  At the conclusion of the Auction, the Selling Debtors shall determine in the exercise of their reasonable business
                  judgment, and in consultation with the Creditors' Committee, which bidder submitted the "highest or best" offer, as
                  the case may be, immediately preceding the making of the Prevailing Bid (the "Backup Bid"). The bidder making the
                  Backup Bid (the "Backup Bid") shall be required to keep the Backup Bid open and irrevocable until the earlier of: (i)
                  the Offer Expiration Date; or (ii) the consummation of the sale transaction contemplated by the Prevailing Bid. In the
                  event the Stalking Horse Bidder becomes the Backup Bidder pursuant to this § 13(b),  [*300] and the Backup Bid
                  expires pursuant to § 13(b)(ii), the amount of the Breakup Fee shall increase by $ 500,000.
                  Upon termination pursuant to the APA, the Selling Debtors will be authorized, but not required, to consummate a
                  sale transaction with the Backup Bidder on the terms and conditions of the Backup Bid (the "Backup Purchase")
                  without further order of the Bankruptcy Court. The Selling Debtors shall consult with the Creditors' Committee in
                  determining whether to consummate the Backup Purchase.
                  For purposes of consummating the Backup Purchase, the Closing Deadline shall be extended for the number of
                  days between Sale Hearing and the date the Selling Debtors notify the Backup Bidder that they intend to
                  consummate the Backup Purchase plus twenty (20) additional days.
                  The Backup Bidder shall be subject to the provisions of § 13(a).
                  14. Return of Deposits.
                  Except as otherwise provided herein, all Deposits (including interest or investment income accrued thereon - if any)
                  shall be returned to bidders not selected by the Selling Debtors as the Prevailing Bidder or Backup Bidder no later
                  man five (5) business days following the conclusion of the Auction. The Deposit (including interest or investment
                  [*301] income accrued thereon - if any) of the Backup Bidder shall be returned on or prior to the earlier of: (i) one
                  (1) business day following the consummation of the sale transaction contemplated by the Prevailing Bid; and (ii)
                  one (1) business day following the Offer Expiration Date.
                  15. Reservation of Rights: Deadline Extension.
                  Consistent with these Bidding Procedures, the Selling Debtors reserve their rights to modify these bidding
                  procedures and auction procedures at any time before and during the Auction, including, without limitation,
                  extending the deadlines set forth herein (with the exception of the Backup Bid-related Deadlines), modifying bidding
                  increments, adjourning the Auction at the Auction and/or adjourning the Sale Hearing in open court without further
                  notice, re-opening the Auction at any time prior to the Sale Hearing, canceling the Auction, and rejecting all
                  Qualifying Bids if, in the Selling Debtors' business judgment, no submitted bid is for a fair and adequate price. The
                  Selling Debtors will consult with the Creditors' Committee regarding their exercise of the rights reserved in the
                  foregoing sentence.
                  Dated: July [   ], 2007

                  EXHIBIT A to BIDDING PROCEDURES
                  Form of Asset Purchase Agreement
                  Exhibit C to Sale Motion
                  Form of Cure Notice
                  [Attached]
                  IN THE UNITED STATES BANKRUPTCY COURT FOR THE DISTRICT OF DELAWARE
                  
                  
                  In re DURA AUTOMOTIVE SYSTEMS, INC., et al., 1 Debtors.
                  Chapter 11
                  Case No. 06-11202 (KJC)
                  Jointly Administered
                  LEASE OR EXECUTORY CONTRACT ASSUMPTION AND CURE NOTICE
                  PLEASE TAKE NOTICE that, on July 3, 2007, the Debtors filed a Motion for Entry of an Order: (a) Approving
                  Bidding Procedures with Bid Protections: (b) Approving Form and Manner of Notice of Sale by Auction; (c)
                  Authorizing  [*303] Sale of Assets Free and Clear of All Liens, Claims, Encumbrances and Other Interests; (d)
                  Authorizing Assumption and Assignment of Executory Contracts; and (e) Approving Procedures for Noticing and
                  Determining Cure Amounts (the "Sale Motion") [Docket No.    ] with the United States Bankruptcy Court for the
                  District of Delaware (the "Bankruptcy Court"). The Debtors seek, among other things, to sell their Atwood Mobile
                  Products division (the "Sale Assets") to the successful bidder at an auction (the "Prevailing Bidder"), free and clear
                  of all liens, claims, encumbrances and other interests pursuant to section 363 of the Bankruptcy Code, and to
                  assume and assign to the Prevailing Bidder certain executory contracts (the "Executory Contracts") pursuant to
                  section 365 of the Bankruptcy Code.
                  PLEASE TAKE FURTHER NOTICE that, on [   ], 2007, the Bankruptcy Court entered an order [Docket No.    ] (the
                  "Bidding Procedures Order") approving the following cure procedures (the "Cure Procedures"):
                  (i) Notice of Cure Objection Deadline: Within five (5) business days following entry of the Bidding Procedures
                  Order (the "Initial Cure Notice Date"), the Debtors shall serve the Cure Notice by regular mail  [*304] on each
                  counterparty to an Executory Contract (a "Contract Counterparty"), notifying such Contract Counterparty of the
                  Debtors' intent to assume and assign the applicable Executory Contract and of the cure amount determined by
                  the Debtors to be necessary for such assumption and assignment. If Schedule 2.1(c) of the APA is
                  subsequently amended to add executory contracts or unexpired leases, the Debtors shall serve the Cure
                  Notice via overnight courier within three (3) business days of such amendment.
                  (ii) Cure Objections: Any Contract Counterparty seeking to (a) assert a Cure Amount based on defaults,
                  conditions or pecuniary losses under an Executory Contract different from that set forth on the applicable Cure
                  Notice, or (b) object to the potential assumption and assignment on any other grounds, shall be required to file
                  and serve a written objection (a "Cure Objection") setting forth with specificity (i) any and all cure amounts that
                  the Contract Counterparty asserts must be cured or satisfied respecting an Executory Contract and/or (ii) if the
                  objection to the potential assignment of such Executory Contract is based on adequate assurance issues, what
                  information with respect to the  [*305] Purchaser such Contract Counterparty requires to satisfy its adequate
                  assurance concerns.
                  (iii) Cure Objection Deadline: To be considered timely, a Cure Objection must be filed with the Bankruptcy
                  Court no later than 4:00 p.m. (prevailing Eastern time) on August 8, 2007 (the "Cure Objection Deadline"). If,
                  after the Initial Cure Notice Date, the Debtors subsequently amend Schedule 2.1(c) of the APA to add
                  executory contracts or unexpired leases, the Cure Objection Deadline with respect to such Executory Contracts
                  shall be the earlier of (i) fourteen (14) calendar days from the date of service of a Cure Notice or (ii) August 15,
                  2007, at 11:00 a.m. (prevailing Eastern time).
                  (iv) Failure to File Cure Objection: Unless a Cure Objection is timely filed by the Cure Objection Deadline, the
                  Bankruptcy Court shall enter an order authorizing or effecting the assumption and assignment of the applicable
                  1 The "Debtors" comprise the entities set forth in the Order Pursuant to Rule 1015(b) of the Federal Rules of Bankruptcy
                  Procedure Directing Joint Administration of the Debtors' Chapter 11 Cases, entered on October 31, 2006 [Docket No. 68].
                  
                  
                  Executory Contract at the Sale Hearing or otherwise without regard to any objection such party may have or
                  any provisions to the contrary in the applicable Executory Contract.
                  (v) Waiver of Cure Objection: Contract Counterparties that fail to file Cure Objections as provided above shall
                  be deemed  [*306] to have waived and released any and all Cure Obligations and shall be forever barred and
                  estopped from asserting or claiming against the Debtors, the Prevailing Bidder or any other assignee of the
                  relevant Executory Contract that any additional amounts are due or defaults exist, or prohibitions or conditions
                  to assignment exist or must be satisfied, under such Executory Contracts for the period prior to the
                  consummation of the APA. The Sale Order shall provide that the Prevailing Bidder's promise to perform under
                  the Executory Contracts is deemed, absent objection, adequate assurance of future performance under the
                  Executory Contracts.
                  (vi) Reservation of Rights: The Debtors and Prevailing Bidder each reserve the right to exclude or add any
                  Executory Contracts from or to Schedule 2.1(c) of the APA and to withdraw the request to assume and assign
                  any Executory Contract pursuant to the terms of the APA.
                  (vii) Unresolved Cure Objections:  [*307] Any Cure Objections, if not consensually resolved, will be heard by
                  the Bankruptcy Court at the Sale Hearing, where the Debtors will demonstrate facts to establish the Prevailing
                  Bidder's capability and willingness to perform under the Executory Contracts.
                  PLEASE TAKE FURTHER NOTICE that the Debtors may seek, in connection with the sale of the Sale
                  Assets, to assume or assign the unexpired lease(s) and/or executory contract(s) identified on Exhibit A
                  attached hereto. The cure amount(s) the Debtors believe is/are due and owing, within the meaning of
                  section 365(b)(1) of the Bankruptcy Code, for those contracts, based on the Debtors' books and records, is
                  set forth in Exhibit A. Such Cure Amount includes any and all outstanding pre-petition amounts.
                  PLEASE TAKE FURTHER NOTICE that a hearing will be held to approve the assumption and assignment of the
                  Executory Contracts and sale of the Sale Assets to the Prevailing Bidder (the "Sale Hearing") before the Hon. Kevin
                  J. Carey, United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of Delaware, 824 North Market Street, 5th Floor,

                  Exhibit H to Asset Purchase Agreement
                  IN THE UNITED STATES BANKRUPTCY COURT FOR THE DISTRICT OF DELAWARE

                  SALE OF DEBTORS' ATWOOD MOBILE PRODUCTS DIVISION
                  ORDER: (A) APPROVING BIDDING PROCEDURES WITH BID PROTECTIONS; (B) APPROVING FORM AND
                  MANNER OF NOTICE OF SALE BY AUCTION; AND (C) APPROVING PROCEDURES FOR NOTICING AND
                  DETERMINING CURE AMOUNTS
                  THIS MATTER is before the court on the motion (the "Motion") 2 [Docket No.    ] dated July 3, 2007, of the Debtors
                  for entry of an order approving, among other things: (a) bidding procedures with bid protections; (b) the form and
                  manner of notice of sale by auction; and (c) procedures for noticing and determining cure amounts. After due
                  deliberation and having determined that the relief requested in the Motion is in the best interests of the Debtors and
                  their estates,
                  THE  [*314] COURT HEREBY FINDS THAT:
                  3
                  1 The "Debtors" comprise  [*313] the entities set forth in the Order Pursuant to Rule 1015(b) of the Federal Rules of Bankruptcy
                  Procedure Directing Joint Administration of the Debtors' Chapter 11 Cases, entered on October 31, 2006 [Docket No. 68].
                  2 Unless otherwise stated, all capitalized terms not defined herein shall have the same meaning as set forth in the APA and the
                  Motion, and to the extent of any inconsistency, the APA shall govern.
                  3 The findings and conclusions set forth herein constitute the court's findings of fact and conclusions of law pursuant to
                  Bankruptcy Rule 7052, made applicable to this proceeding pursuant to Bankruptcy Rule 9014. To the extent that any of the
                  following findings of fact constitute conclusions of law, they are adopted as such. To the extent any of the following conclusions
                  of law constitute findings of fact, they are adopted as such.
                  
                  
                  A. This court has jurisdiction over the Motion pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1334. This proceeding is a core proceeding
                  pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 157(b)(2)(A), (N) and (O). Venue is proper in this district and in this court pursuant to 28
                  U.S.C. §§ 1408 and 1409.
                  B. The statutory predicates for the relief requested herein are sections 105(a), 363(b) and (f), 365, 503 and 507 of
                  title 11 of the United States Code (the "Bankruptcy Code") and Rules 2002(a)(2), 6004(a), (b), (c), (e) and (f),
                  6006(a) and (c), 9007 and 9014 of the Federal Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure (the "Bankruptcy Rules").
                  C. Notice of the Motion having been given to the Notice Parties (as defined below) is sufficient in light of the
                  circumstances and the nature of the relief  [*315] requested herein.
                  D. The Debtors have articulated good and sufficient reasons for this court to grant the relief requested in the Motion
                  regarding the sales process, including, without limitation: (i) approval of the Bidding Procedures with bid protections;
                  (ii) the form and manner of notice of sale by auction; and (iii) procedures for noticing and determining cure amounts.
                  E. The Breakup Fee and Expense Reimbursement to be paid under the circumstances described herein and in the
                  APA to the Purchaser are: (i) actual and necessary costs and expenses of preserving the Debtors estates within the
                  meaning of sections 503(b)(1) and 507(a)(2) of the Bankruptcy Code; (ii) commensurate to the real and substantial
                  benefit conferred upon the Debtors' estates by the Purchaser, (iii) reasonable and appropriate, in light of the size
                  and nature of the proposed sale transaction and comparable transactions, the commitments that have been made
                  and the efforts that have been and will be expended by the Purchaser; and (iv) necessary to induce the Purchaser
                  to continue to pursue the sale transaction and to continue to be bound by the APA.
                  F. The Breakup Fee and Expense Reimbursement also induced the Purchaser  [*316] to submit a bid that will serve
                  as a minimum floor bid on which the Debtors, their creditors and other bidders may rely. The Purchaser has
                  provided a material benefit to the Debtors and their creditors by increasing the likelihood that Debtors receive the
                  best possible price for the Sale Assets. Accordingly, the Bidding Procedures, Breakup Fee and Expense
                  Reimbursement are reasonable and appropriate and represent the best method for maximizing value for the benefit
                  of the Debtors' estates.
                  G. The Sale Notice (attached hereto as Exhibit A) is reasonably calculated to provide all interested parties with
                  timely and proper notice of the Sale, Sale Hearing and Auction.
                  H. The Cure Notice (attached hereto as Exhibit B) is reasonably calculated to provide all counterparties to the
                  Executory Contracts (the "Contract Parties") with proper notice of the potential assumption and assignment of their
                  executory contract or unexpired lease and any cure amounts relating thereto.
                  IT IS HEREBY ORDERED, ADJUDGED AND DECREED THAT:
                  1. The Bidding Procedures, substantially in the form attached hereto as Exhibit C, are hereby approved. The
                  Debtors are authorized to take any and all actions necessary or appropriate  [*317] to implement the Bidding
                  Procedures.
                  2. All objections to the relief requested in the Motion that have not been withdrawn, waived, or settled as announced
                  to the court at the hearing on the Motion or by stipulation filed with the court, are overruled except as otherwise set
                  forth herein.
                  3. Within five (5) business days of this order, the Debtors (or their agent) shall serve by first class mail, postage
                  prepaid, copies of: (i) this order; (ii) the Bidding Procedures; (iii) the APA; and (iv) the Sale Notice, including the
                  date, time and place of the Auction, and the time fixed for the filing of objections to the Sale, upon the following
                  entities (collectively, the "Notice Parties"): 4
                  4 The Sale Notice will direct parties to contact Kirkland & Ellis LLP, counsel to the Debtors, for more information and will provide
                  that any party that wishes to obtain a copy of any related document (subject to any necessary confidentiality agreement) may
                  
                  
                  (i) the United States Trustee;
                  (ii) counsel to the Creditors' Committee;
                  (iii) counsel to the agent for the Debtors' postpetition secured lenders;
                  (iv) counsel to the agent to the Debtors' prepetition second lien secured lenders;
                  (v) counsel to the agent for the Debtors' prepetition first lien lenders;
                  (vi) counsel to the ad hoc committee of certain of the Debtors' prepetition second lien secured lenders;
                  (vii) the Securities and Exchange Commission;
                  (viii) all taxing authorities having jurisdiction over any of  [*318] the Sale Assets, including the Internal Revenue
                  Service;
                  (ix) the United States Department of Justice;
                  (x) each of (a) the United States Environmental Protection Agency; (b) the California Department of Conservation;
                  (c) the California Department of Toxic Substances; (d) the California Department of Water Resources; (e) the
                  California Environmental Protection Agency; (i) the California Integrated Waste Management Board; (g) the Indiana
                  Department of Natural Resources; (h) the Indiana Department of Environmental Management; (i) the Iowa
                  Department of Natural Resources; (j) the Ohio Air Quality Development Authority; (k) the Ohio Environmental
                  Protection Agency; (l) the Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources; (m) the Pennsylvania
                  Department of Environmental Protection; (n) the Tennessee Department of Environment and Conservation; and (o)
                  the Utah Department of Environmental Quality;
                  (xi) all parties that have requested special notice pursuant to Bankruptcy Rule 2002;
                  (xii) all persons or entities known to the Debtors that have or have asserted a lien on, or security interest in, all or
                  any portion of the Sale Assets;
                  (xiii) all Contract Parties;
                  (xiv) counsel to the  [*319] Purchaser, and
                  (xv) all potential bidders previously identified or otherwise known to the Debtors.
                  4. Within seven (7) business days of the entry of the Bidding Procedures Order, the Debtors will publish a notice,
                  substantially in the form of the Sale Notice, in the National Edition of the Wall Street Journal, the Detroit Free Press,
                  the Automotive News and the South Bend Tribune, and such other publications as the Debtors and their advisors
                  determine will promote the marketing and sale of the Sale Assets to other interested parties whose identities are
                  unknown to the Debtors.
                  5. The Breakup Fee and Expense Reimbursement as  [*320] set forth in die APA are hereby approved. If the
                  Purchaser becomes entitled to receive the Breakup Fee and Expense Reimbursement in accordance with the terms
                  of the APA, then the Purchaser shall be, and hereby is, granted an allowed administrative claim in the Debtors'
                  chapter 11 cases in an amount equal to the Breakup Fee and Expense Reimbursement, under sections 503(b)(1)
                  and 507(a)(2) of the Bankruptcy Code.
                  make such a request in writing to Kirkland & Ellis LLP, 200 East Randolph Drive, Chicago, IL 60601 (Attn: Roger J. Higgins),
                  Telephone: (312) 861-2000, Facsimile: (312) 861-2200, or by accessing the website of the Debtors' claims and noticing agent,
                  Kurtzman Carson Consultants LLC, at http://dura.kccllc.net/dura.
                  
                  
                  6. The Breakup Fee and Expense Reimbursement shall have priority over any and all claims of holders with existing
                  liens on proceeds of an Alternative Transaction (as defined in the Bidding Procedures) or the Sale Assets, as the
                  case may be.
                  7. The Breakup Fee shall be payable at the time of closing of an Alternative Transaction from the closing proceeds.
                  The Expense Reimbursement shall be payable on or before the earlier of: (x) 20 days from the date of entry of the
                  order approving an Alternative Transaction; or (y) the closing of an Alternative Transaction.
                  8. The Debtors are authorized and directed, without further action or order by the court, to pay the Breakup Fee and
                  Expense Reimbursement in accordance with the terms and conditions of the APA and this order.
                  9. No person or  [*321] entity, other than the Purchaser, shall be entitled to any expense reimbursement, breakup
                  fee, "topping," termination, or other similar fee or payment.
                  10. The Cure Procedures, as set forth in the Cure Notice, are hereby approved.
                  11. The Sale Hearing will commence at 1:30 p.m. (prevailing Eastern time), August 15, 2007. The Sale Hearing
                  may be adjourned or rescheduled without notice other than by an announcement of the adjourned date at the Sale
                  Hearing, as set forth in the Bidding Procedures.
                  12. On or before 4:00 p.m. (prevailing Eastern time) on August 8, 2007 (the "Objection Deadlined"),
                  objections, if any, to the remainder of the relief requested in the Sale Motion must: (a) be in writing and filed with
                  this court; (b) comply with the Federal Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure and the Local Bankruptcy Rules; and (c) be
                  served upon the Debtors and the Notice Parties (so as to be received on or before the Objection Deadline).
                  13. Notwithstanding the possible applicability of Bankruptcy Rules 6004(h), 7062, 9014 or otherwise, the terms and
                  conditions of this order shall be immediately effective and enforceable upon its entry.
                  14. All time periods set forth in this order shall be calculated  [*322] in accordance with Bankruptcy Rule 9006(a).
                  15. The Debtors are authorized and empowered to take all actions necessary to implement the relief granted in this
                  order.
                  16. To the extent that this order is inconsistent with any prior order or pleading with respect to the Motion in these
                  cases, the terms of this order shall govern.
                  17. This court shall retain jurisdiction to resolve any dispute relating to the interpretation of the terms and conditions
                  of the APA and this order. To the extent any provisions of this order shall be inconsistent with the Motion, the terms
                  of this order shall control.
                  Date:    , 2007
                  SO ORDERED:
                  Hon. Kevin J. Carey
                  United States Bankruptcy Judge

                  LEASE OR EXECUTORY CONTRACT ASSUMPTION AND CURE NOTICE
                  PLEASE TAKE NOTICE that, on July 3, 2007, the Debtors filed a Motion for Entry of an Order: (a) Approving
                  Bidding Procedures with Bid Protections; (b) Approving Form and Manner of Notice of Sale by Auction; (c)
                  Authorizing Sale of Assets Free and Clear of All Liens, Claims, Encumbrances and Other Interests; (d) Authorizing
                  Assumption and Assignment of Executory Contracts; and (e) Approving Procedures for Noticing and Determining
                  Cure Amounts (the "Sale Motion")  [*327] [Docket No.    ] with the United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of
                  Delaware (the "Bankruptcy Court"). The Debtors seek, among other things, to sell their Atwood Mobile Products
                  division (the "Sale Assets") to the successful bidder at an auction (the "Prevailing Bidder"), free and clear of all
                  liens, claims, encumbrances and other interests pursuant to section 363 of the Bankruptcy Code, and to assume
                  and assign to the Prevailing Bidder certain executory contracts (the "Executory Contracts") pursuant to section 365
                  of the Bankruptcy Code.
                  PLEASE TAKE FURTHER NOTICE that, on [   ], 2007, the Bankruptcy Court entered an order [Docket No.    ] (the
                  "Bidding Procedures Order") approving the following cure procedures (the "Cure Procedures"):
                  (i) Notice of Cure Objection Deadline: Within five (5) business days following entry of the Bidding Procedures
                  Order (the "Initial Cure Notice Date"), the Debtors shall serve the Cure Notice by regular mail on each
                  counterparty to an Executory Contract (a "Contract Counterparty"), notifying such Contract Counterparty of the
                  Debtors' intent to assume and assign the applicable Executory Contract and of the cure amount determined by
                  the Debtors  [*328] to be necessary for such assumption and assignment. If Schedule 2.1(c) of the APA is
                  subsequently amended to add executory contracts or unexpired leases, the Debtors shall serve the Cure
                  Notice via overnight courier within three (3) business days of such amendment.
                  (ii) Cure Objections: Any Contract Counterparty seeking to (a) assert a Cure Amount based on defaults,
                  conditions or pecuniary losses under an Executory Contract different from that set forth on the applicable Cure
                  Notice, or (b) object to the potential assumption and assignment on any other grounds, shall be required to file
                  and serve a written objection (a "Cure Objection") setting forth with specificity (i) any and all cure amounts that
                  the Contract Counterparty asserts must be cured or satisfied respecting an Executory Contract and/or (ii) if the
                  objection to the potential assignment of such Executory Contract is based on adequate assurance issues, what
                  information with respect to the Purchaser such Contract Counterparty requires to satisfy its adequate
                  assurance concerns.
                  (iii) Cure Objection Deadline: To be considered timely, a Cure Objection must be filed with the Bankruptcy
                  Court no later than 4:00 p.m. (prevailing  [*329] Eastern time) on August 8, 2007 (die "Cure Objection
                  Deadline"). If, after the Initial Cure Notice Date, the Debtors subsequently amend Schedule 2.1(c) of the APA
                  to add executory contracts or unexpired leases, the Cure Objection Deadline with respect to such Executory
                  Contracts shall be the earlier of (i) fourteen (14) calendar days from the date of service of a Cure Notice or (ii)
                  August 15, 2007, at 11:00 a.m. (prevailing Eastern time).
                  (iv) Failure to File Cure Objection: Unless a Cure Objection is timely filed by the Cure Objection Deadline, the
                  Bankruptcy Court shall enter an order authorizing or effecting the assumption and assignment of me applicable
                  Executory Contract at the Sale Hearing or otherwise without regard to any objection such party may have or
                  any provisions to the contrary in the applicable Executory Contract.
                  (v) Waiver of Cure Objection: Contract Counterparties that fail to file Cure Objections as provided above shall
                  be deemed to have waived and released any and all Cure Obligations and shall be forever barred and
                  estopped from asserting or claiming against the Debtors, the Prevailing Bidder or any other assignee of the
                  
                  
                  relevant Executory Contract that any additional  [*330] amounts are due or defaults exist, or prohibitions or
                  conditions to assignment exist or must be satisfied, under such Executory Contracts for the period prior to the
                  consummation of the APA. The Sale Order shall provide that the Prevailing Bidder's promise to perform under
                  the Executory Contracts is deemed, absent objection, adequate assurance of future performance under the
                  Executory Contracts.
                  (vi) Reservation of Rights: The Debtors and Prevailing Bidder each reserve the right to exclude or add any
                  Executory Contracts from or to Schedule 2.1(c) of the APA and to withdraw the request to assume and assign
                  any Executory Contract pursuant to the terms of the APA.
                  (vii) Unresolved Cure Objections: Any Core Objections, if not consensually resolved, will be heard by the
                  Bankruptcy Court at the Sale Hearing, where the Debtors will demonstrate facts to establish the Prevailing
                  Bidder's capability and willingness to perform under the Executory Contracts.
                  PLEASE TAKE FURTHER NOTICE that the Debtors may seek, in connection with the sale of the Sale
                  Assets, to assume or assign the unexpired lease(s) and/or executory contract(s) identified on Exhibit A
                  attached hereto. The cure amount(s) the Debtors  [*331] believe is/are due and owing, within the meaning of
                  section 365(b)(1) of the Bankruptcy Code, for those contracts, based on the Debtors' books and records, is
                  set forth in Exhibit A. Such Cure Amount includes any and all outstanding pre-petition amounts.
                  PLEASE TAKE FURTHER NOTICE that a hearing will be held to approve the assumption and assignment of the
                  Executory Contracts and sale of the Sale Assets to the Prevailing Bidder (the "Sale Hearing") before the Hon. Kevin
                  J. Carey, United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of Delaware, 824 North Market Street, 5th Floor,
                  Wilmington, Delaware 19801, at 1:30 p.m. (prevailing eastern time), August 15, 2007, or at such time thereafter
                  as counsel may be heard or at such other time as the Bankruptcy Court may determine. The Sale Hearing may be

                  Bidding Procedures
                  [Attached]
                  BIDDING PROCEDURES
                  These bidding procedures set forth the process by which Atwood Mobile Products, Inc., Creation Group Holdings,
                  Inc., Kemberly Creation  [*333] Group, Inc., Creation Group Transportation Group, Inc., Spec-Temp, Inc., and
                  Creation Windows, Inc. (collectively, the "Selling Debtors") are authorized to conduct a sale by auction (the
                  "Auction") of the Sale Assets (defined below). 1
                  1. Sale Assets.
                  The "Sale Assets" consist of the Purchased Assets, as that term is defined in the  [*334] APA.
                  2. Stalking Horse Bidder.
                  On July 3, 2007, the Selling Debtors and Atwood Acquisition Co. LLC (the "Stalking Horse Bidder") entered into an
                  asset purchase agreement for the Sale Assets (the "Stalking Horse APA"), pursuant to which: (i) the Stalking Horse
                  Bidder agreed to pay $ 160,200,000 (the "Stalking Horse Bid") for the Sale Assets, subject to the outcome of the
                  Auction and Bankruptcy Court approval; and (ii) the Selling Debtors agreed, in the event that the Bankruptcy Court
                  approves the purchase of the Sale Assets by another entity (an "Alternative Transaction"): (a) to pay to the Stalking
                  Horse Bidder a breakup fee of two percent (2%) of the Stalking Horse Bid (the "Breakup Fee") plus such additional
                  1 On July    , 2007, the United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of Delaware (the "Bankruptcy Court") (in which the chapter
                  11 bankruptcy cases, jointly administered under Case No. 06-11202 (KJC), of the Selling Debtors and certain of their affiliates--
                  collectively, the "Debtors"--are pending) entered an Order Approving the Bidding Procedures for the Auction and Sale of Atwood
                  Mobile Products [Docket No.    ], thereby approving these bidding procedures.
                  Capitalized terms used, but not defined, herein shall have the meanings ascribed to them in the form of asset purchase
                  agreement attached hereto as Exhibit A (the "APA"), which agreement is identical to the Stalking Horse APA (defined herein) in
                  all material respects except for the exclusion of Section 4.6(c) of the Stalking Horse APA and all other references therein to the
                  Breakup Fee (defined herein).
                  
                  
                  sum as may be applicable under § 13(b) below; and (b) reimburse the Stalking Horse Bidder's reasonable out-of-
                  pocket expenses, including, without limitation, the reasonable fees and expenses of its attorneys, accountants and
                  other advisors, all costs and expenses incident to HSR Act filings, travel expenses, telephone, delivery charges and
                  a reasonable allocation for internal staff and administrative time (the "Expense Reimbursement"), up to an
                  aggregate amount equal to one percent  [*335] (1%) of the Stalking Horse Bid (the "Maximum Expense
                  Reimbursement"). Each of the Breakup Fee and the Expense Reimbursement shall: (x) constitute an allowed
                  administrative expense of the Selling Debtors under Sections 503(b)(1) and 507(a)(2) of the Bankruptcy Code,
                  respectively; and (y) have priority over any and all claims of holders with existing liens on proceeds of an Alternative
                  Transaction or the Purchased Assets, as the case may be. The Breakup Fee shall be payable at the time of closing
                  of an Alternative Transaction from the closing proceeds. The Expense Reimbursement shall be payable on or
                  before the earlier of: (x) 20 days from the date of entry of the order approving an Alternative Transaction or (y) the
                  closing of an Alternative Transaction.
                  3. Due Diligence.
                  Upon execution of a Confidentiality Agreement (as defined below), any party that wishes to conduct reasonable due
                  diligence on the Sale Assets may be granted access to all material information that has been or will be provided to
                  the Stalking Horse Bidder and other bidders; provided, however, that the Selling Debtors have no obligation to
                  provide information after the Bid Deadline (defined below); and provided, further,  [*336] that the Selling Debtors
                  may decline to provide information to parties that, in their reasonable business judgment, have not established that
                  they intend in good faith to and/or have the ability to consummate a purchase of the Sale Assets; provided still
                  further that the Selling Debtors shall consult with the Creditors' Committee regarding any decision to so decline to
                  provide information. 2
                  The Selling Debtors designate Miller Buckfire & Co., LLC to coordinate all reasonable requests for additional
                  information and due diligence access.
                  4. Auction Participation.
                  Subject to § 15 hereof, only the Stalking Horse Bidder and Qualifying Bidders may participate in the Auction. A
                  "Qualifying Bidder" is a party that has: (i) submitted a Qualifying Bid (defined below) to the Selling Debtors; and (ii)
                  executed a confidentiality agreement in form and substance satisfactory to the Selling Debtors (a "Confidentiality
                  Agreement").
                  5. Qualifying Bids.
                  A "Qualifying Bid" is a written offer that:
                  (a) states that the bidder  [*337] offers to purchase all of the Sale Assets upon terms and conditions
                  substantially as set forth in the APA or such alternate purchase and sale agreement that the Selling Debtors
                  determine, in their reasonable business judgment, is no less favorable than the terms and conditions of the
                  APA (a "Modified APA");
                  (b) results in a value to the Selling Debtors in their reasonable business judgment that is more than the
                  "Minimum Bid," which is the sum of: (w) the value of the Stalking Horse Bid, (x)the Breakup Fee, (y) the
                  Maximum Expense Reimbursement, and (z) $ 1,500,000;
                  (c) does not request or entitle the bidder to any transaction or break-up fee, expense reimbursement, or similar
                  type of payment;
                  (d) states that the offer contained therein is irrevocable until 5:00 p.m. (prevailing eastern time), October 1,
                  2007 (the "Offer Expiration Date"), if such bidder is the Prevailing Bidder (defined below) or the Backup Bidder
                  2 The "Creditors' Committee" is the Official Committee of Unsecured Creditors appointed in these chapter 11 cases, and the
                  "Second Lien Group" is the ad hoc committee of Second Lien Lenders.
                  
                  
                  (defined below), and that the bidder is willing to consummate and fund the proposed sale prior to 4:00 p.m.
                  (prevailing eastern time), August 29,2007 (the "Closing Deadline");
                  (e) is accompanied by a cash deposit in the amount equal to ten percent (10%) of the Minimum Bid (each,
                  [*338] a "Deposit");
                  (f) is accompanied by a clean and duty executed APA or Modified APA;
                  (g) is accompanied by a marked Modified APA, if applicable, reflecting the variations from the APA;
                  (h) contains a representation that the bidder (x) has completed a Notification and Report Form for Certain
                  Mergers and Acquisitions (16. C.F.R. Part 803 - Appendix) (an "HSR Notification"), and (y) will file, upon the
                  request of the Selling Debtors, the HSR Notification with the Federal Trade Commission and Department of
                  Justice no later than 5:00 p.m. (prevailing eastern time), August 9,2007;
                  (i) identifies with particularity each and every executory contract and unexpired lease, the assumption and
                  assignment of which is a condition to closing;
                  (j) contains a representation that the bidder is financially capable of consummating the transactions
                  contemplated by the APA or Modified APA;
                  (k) contains financial and other information that the Selling Debtors determine is sufficient to allow them to
                  evaluate and confirm the bidder's financial and other capabilities to consummate the transactions contemplated
                  by the APA or Modified APA, including evidence reasonably satisfactory to the Selling Debtors that such bidder
                  [*339] has received, in writing, debt and/or equity funding commitments (without contingencies) or has
                  financial resources readily available sufficient in the aggregate to finance the purchase of the Sale Assets, and
                  financial and other information establishing adequate assurance of future performance under section 365 of the
                  Bankruptcy Code (which information may be served by the Selling Debtors on contract or lease
                  counterparties);
                  (l) does not contain any due diligence or financing contingencies of any kind;
                  (m) does not include a credit bid by the holder of a lien on equipment and related property of any Debtor such
                  that the offer would make the sale of the remainder of property at the related plants and businesses reasonably
                  impractical at what would otherwise be the highest or best terms, as the case may be, available to the Debtors'
                  estates;
                  (n) fully discloses the identity of each entity that will be bidding for the Sale Assets or otherwise participating in
                  connection with such bid, and the complete terms of any such participation; and
                  (o) includes evidence of authorization and approval from the bidder's board of directors (or comparable
                  governing body) with respect to the submission,  [*340] execution, delivery and closing of the APA or Modified
                  APA.
                  6. Bid Deadline.
                  Each party other than the Stalking Horse Bidder wishing to participate in the Auction must submit a written offer (via
                  e-mail, fax or other means) so as to be received prior to 5:00 p.m. (prevailing eastern time), August 8, 2007 (the
                  "Bid Deadline"), by:
                  (a) Selling Debtors' Investment Bankers: Miller Buckfire & Co., LLC, 250 Park Avenue, 19th Floor, New York,
                  New York 10177, Fax: 212-895-1853, Attn: Durc A. Savini (durc.savini@millerbuckfire.com) and Alexander
                  Tracy (alexander.tracy@millerbuckfire.com); and
                  (b) Selling Debtors'

Counsel: Kirkland & Ellis LLP, 200 East Randolph Drive, Chicago, Illinois 60601-6636, Fax:
                  312-861-2200,
                  Attn:
                  Marc
                  Kieselstein,
                  P.C.
                  (mkieselstein@kirkland.com),
                  Roger
                  J.
                  Higgins
                  (rhiggins@kirkland.com), Michael G. Timmers, P.C. (mtimmers@kirkland.com), and Ryan B. Bennett
                  (rbennett@kirkland.com).
                  
                  
                  The Selling Debtors further reserve the right, in their reasonable business judgment, at any time after the Bid
                  Deadline and prior to the conclusion of the Auction, to invite parties that have not previously submitted written offers
                  to do so such that they may be considered pursuant to the procedures  [*341] set forth herein.
                  The Selling Debtors shall provide counsel to the Creditors' Committee, Second Lien Group and DIP Lenders with
                  copies of bids, and a list of parties submitting bids, as soon as is reasonably practicable after the Bid Deadline.
                  7. Determination of Qualifying Bids.
                  The Selling Debtors shall, by no later than 5:00 p.m. (prevailing eastern time), August 10, 2007 (me "Bid
                  Determination Deadline"):
                  (a) determine in their reasonable business judgment whether a written offer is a Qualifying Bid;
                  (b) notify each party submitting a written offer whether that written offer is a Qualifying Bid; and
                  (c) provide copies of each Qualifying Bidders' APA to the Stalking Horse Bidder and all Qualifying Bidders.
                  The Selling Debtors shall consult with the Creditors' Committee regarding their determination of Qualifying Bidders.
                  The Selling Debtors will provide to counsel for the Creditors' Committee, Second Lien Group and DIP Lenders the
                  list of Qualifying Bidders as soon as is reasonably practicable after the Bid Determination Deadline.
                  The Selling Debtors reserve the right, at any time after the Bid Deadline and prior to the commencement of the
                  Auction, to request parties submitting written  [*342] offers that were determined not to be Qualifying Bids to amend
                  their written offers such that those amended written offers may be considered as Qualifying Bids. The Selling
                  Debtors will consult with the Creditors' Committee regarding any such requests.
                  8. Auction Procedures.
                  In the event that the Selling Debtors receive one or more Qualifying Bids, the Auction shall take place at 10:00 a.m.
                  (prevailing eastern time), August 14, 2007, at the offices of Kirkland & Ellis LLP, Citigroup Center, 153 East 53rd
                  Street, New York, New York 10022, or at any such other place, date and time as may be designated in writing by
                  the Selling Debtors. Subject to § 15 hereof, the Auction shall be governed by the following procedures:
                  (a) the Stalking Horse Bidder and each Qualifying Bidder shall appear in person or by telephone, or through a
                  duly authorized representative;
                  (b) the Stalking Horse Bidder and each Qualifying Bidder shall be required to confirm that it has not engaged in
                  any collusion with respect to the bidding or the sale (except for joint bidding arrangements disclosed to the
                  Selling Debtors pursuant to § 5(n));
                  (c) only the Stalking Horse Bidder and Qualifying Bidders shall be entitled to  [*343] submit bids;
                  (d) bidding shall commence at the amount of the highest Qualifying Bid submitted prior to the Auction;
                  (e) the Selling Debtors reserve the right to determine, in their reasonable business judgment, whether a bid
                  constitutes a higher and better offer than previous bids, based upon factors including, but not limited to, the
                  amount of the purchase price, the form of consideration being offered, the likelihood of the bidder's ability to
                  close a transaction and the timing thereof, the number, type and nature of any changes to the APA requested,
                  and the net benefit to the Selling Debtors' estates;
                  (f) bids must be at least $ 750,000 (the "Auction Bid Increment") higher than the outstanding highest bid
                  (though, as discussed in § 15 hereof, the Selling Debtors retain the right to modify, in their business judgment,
                  the bid increment during the Auction); provided, however, that any further bid made by the Stalking Horse
                  Bidder shall include a credit (or Purchase Price reduction) equal to the Breakup Fee plus the Maximum
                  Expense Reimbursement (the sum of which is the "Credit Bid Amount"), such that any such bid by the Stalking
                  Horse shall result in an increase in value to the Selling  [*344] Debtors equal to the Auction Bid Increment 3
                  3 For example, if a Qualifying Bidder bids $ 200,000,000, the Stalking Horse may then bid $ 200,750,000, which includes the
                  Credit Bid Amount, and which will result in an increase in value to the Selling Debtors equal to the Auction Bid Increment.
                  
                  
                  This same Credit Bid Amount shall reduce the Purchase Price in the event that the Stalking Horse Bidder is the
                  Prevailing Bidder;
                  (g) the Stalking Horse Bidder and Qualifying Bidders may make additional modifications to the Stalking Horse
                  APA, APA or Modified APA, as applicable, during the Auction, provided, however, that any such modifications,
                  on an aggregate basis, shall not be less favorable to the Selling Debtors as determined by the Selling Debtors
                  in their reasonable business judgment;
                  (h) the Selling Debtors intend to continue the Auction until there is only one bid that, in their reasonable
                  business judgment, is the highest or best offer, as the case may be (the "Prevailing Bid"--the bidder submitting
                  such Prevailing Bid, the "Prevailing Bidder," shall have such rights and responsibilities as set forth in the
                  applicable APA or Modified APA); provided that the Debtors will consult with the Creditors' Committee
                  regarding the selection of the Prevailing Bidder;
                  (i) the Selling Debtors may, at any time prior to the commencement of the Sale Hearing (defined below),
                  continue the Auction from time to time, adjourn the Auction, and re-open  [*345] the Auction; and
                  (j) the Stalking Horse Bidder and each Qualifying Bidder participating in the Auction shall be deemed to have
                  consented to the core jurisdiction of the Bankruptcy Court.
                  9. No Qualifying Bids.
                  If no Qualifying Bid is submitted by the Bid Deadline, the Selling Debtors may, but are not required, in their
                  reasonable business judgment, cancel the Auction and accept the Stalking Horse Bid (in which case, the Prevailing
                  Bid shall be the Stalking Horse Bid, and the Prevailing Bidder shall be die Stalking Horse Bidder). Prior to
                  announcing any such cancellation, the Selling Debtors shall consult with the Creditors' Committee regarding that
                  cancellation.
                  10. Announcement of Prevailing Bidder and Execution of Agreements.
                  The Selling Debtors reserve the right to announce the identity of the Prevailing Bidder at any time prior to the
                  commencement of the Sale Hearing. Within one (1) calendar day after the announcement of the identity of the
                  [*346] Prevailing Bidder by the Selling Debtors, the Prevailing Bidder shall complete and execute all agreements,
                  contracts, instruments or other documents evidencing and containing the terms and conditions upon which the
                  Prevailing Bid was made.
                  11. Selling Debtors' Acceptance of Prevailing Bid Subject to Bankruptcy Court Approval.
                  The Prevailing Bid will be subject to approval by the Bankruptcy Court at the Sale Hearing. The Selling Debtors
                  shall be deemed to have accepted the Prevailing Bid only when the Prevailing Bid has been approved by the
                  Bankruptcy Court. The Selling Debtors shall use reasonable efforts to obtain Bankruptcy Court approval of the
                  Prevailing Bid in the form of the sale order attached as Exhibit I to the APA (the "Sale Order").
                  12. Sale Hearing.
                  A hearing (the "Sale Hearing") will be held to approve the sale of the Sale Assets to the Prevailing Bidder before the
                  Honorable Kevin J. Carey in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of Delaware, 824 North Market
                  Street, 5th Floor, Wilmington, Delaware 19801, at 1:30 p.m. (prevailing eastern time), August 15, 2007, at such
                  time thereafter as counsel may be heard, or at such other time as the Bankruptcy Court may  [*347] determine. The
                  Sale Hearing may be adjourned from time to time without further notice to creditors or parties-in-interest other than
                  by announcement of the adjournment in open court on the date scheduled for the Sale Hearing. The Prevailing
                  Bidder and Backup Bidder (defined below), if any, should be represented by counsel at the Sale Hearing.
                  13. Consummation of the Purchase.
                  (a) Closing Deadline.
                  
                  
                  The Prevailing Bidder shall, subject to the terms and conditions set forth in the Prevailing Bidder's APA,
                  consummate the sale transaction contemplated by the Prevailing Bid (the "Purchase") on or before the Closing
                  Deadline (defined in § 5(d) above). Consistent with APA § 8.4, the Prevailing Bidder and the Selling Debtors shall
                  each use their commercially reasonable best efforts to: (i) take all actions necessary or appropriate to consummate
                  the transactions contemplated by the APA and (ii) cause the fulfillment at the earliest practicable date of all of the
                  conditions to their respective obligations to consummate the transactions contemplated by this Agreement. The
                  Selling Debtors and Prevailing Bidder (in consultation with the Creditors' Committee) may agree to extend the
                  Closing Deadline  [*348] from time to time in their reasonable business judgment.
                  If the Prevailing Bidder's APA is terminated in accordance with the terms thereof, the Selling Debtors may, in their
                  reasonable business judgment, close the Backup Purchase with the Backup Bidder pursuant to § 13(b), and the
                  Selling Debtors reserve all of their rights under the APA to obtain damages from the Prevailing Bidder.
                  (b) Backup Purchase.
                  At the conclusion of the Auction, the Selling Debtors shall determine in the exercise of their reasonable business
                  judgment, and in consultation with the Creditors' Committee, which bidder submitted the "highest or best" offer, as
                  the case may be, immediately preceding the making of the Prevailing Bid (the "Backup Bid"). The bidder making the
                  Backup Bid (the "Backup Bid") shall be required to keep the Backup Bid open and irrevocable until the earlier of: (i)
                  the Offer Expiration Date; or (ii) the consummation of the sale transaction contemplated by the Prevailing Bid. In the
                  event the Stalking Horse Bidder becomes the Backup Bidder pursuant to this § 13(b), and the Backup Bid expires
                  pursuant to § 13(b)(ii), the amount of the Breakup Fee shall increase by $ 500,000.
                  Upon termination pursuant  [*349] to the APA, the Selling Debtors will be authorized, but not required, to
                  consummate a sale transaction with the Backup Bidder on the terms and conditions of the Backup Bid (the "Backup
                  Purchase") without further order of the Bankruptcy Court. The Selling Debtors shall consult with the Creditors'
                  Committee in determining whether to consummate the Backup Purchase.
                  For purposes of consummating the Backup Purchase, the Closing Deadline shall be extended for the number of
                  days between Sale Hearing and the date the Selling Debtors notify the Backup Bidder that they intend to
                  consummate the Backup Purchase plus twenty (20) additional days.
                  The Backup Bidder shall be subject to the provisions of § 13(a).
                  14. Return of Deposits.
                  Except as otherwise provided herein, all Deposits (including interest or investment income accrued thereon - if any)
                  shall be returned to bidders not selected by the Selling Debtors as the Prevailing Bidder or Backup Bidder no later
                  than five (5) business days following the conclusion of the Auction. The Deposit (including interest or investment
                  income accrued thereon - if any) of the Backup Bidder shall be returned on or prior to the earlier of: (i) one (1)
                  business day  [*350] following the consummation of the sale transaction contemplated by the Prevailing Bid; and (ii)
                  one (1) business day following the Offer Expiration Date.
                  15. Reservation of Rights: Deadline Extension.
                  Consistent with these Bidding Procedures, the Selling Debtors reserve their rights to modify these bidding
                  procedures and auction procedures at any time before and during the Auction, including, without limitation,
                  extending the deadlines set forth herein (with the exception of the Backup Bid-related Deadlines), modifying bidding
                  increments, adjourning the Auction at the Auction and/or adjourning the Sale Hearing in open court without further
                  notice, re-opening the Auction at any time prior to the Sale Hearing, canceling the Auction, and rejecting all
                  Qualifying Bids if, in the Selling Debtors' business judgment, no submitted bid is for a fair and adequate price. The
                  Selling Debtors will consult with the Creditors' Committee regarding their exercise of the rights reserved in the
                  foregoing sentence.

                  ORDER: (A) AUTHORIZING THE SALE OF CERTAIN ASSETS FREE AND CLEAR OF ALL LIENS, CLAIMS,
