                  EXECUTORY CONTRACTS IN CONNECTION THEREWITH
                  This matter is before the Court on the motion (the "Sale Motion")  [*352] [Docket No.    ], dated    , 2007, the
                  Debtors, for entry of an order, pursuant to 11 U.S.C. §§ 105(a), 363, and 365 (the "Bankruptcy Code"), and Rules
                  2002, 6004, 6006, 9007 and 9014 of the Federal Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure (the "Bankruptcy Rules"): (a)
                  approving the Bidding Procedures; (b) approving the form and manner of notice of a Sale by Auction; (c) authorizing
                  the Sale of certain Assets free and clear of all Liens, Claims, Encumbrances and other Interests; (d) authorizing the
                  Assumption and Assignment of certain Executory Contracts in connection therewith; and (e) approving procedures
                  for determining Cure Amounts in connection therewith; and the Court having heard statements of counsel and the
                  evidence presented in support of the relief requested by the Debtors in the Sale Motion at a hearing before the
                  Court on    , 2007 (the "Sale Hearing"); and it appearing that the Court has jurisdiction over this matter, and it further
                  appearing that the legal and factual bases set forth in the Sale Motion and at the Sale Hearing establish just cause
                  for the relief granted herein; and after due deliberation thereon,
                  THE COURT HEREBY FINDS AND DETERMINES THAT:
                  I. Jurisdiction, Final Order  [*353] and Statutory Predicates
                  A. The Court has jurisdiction to hear and determine the Sale Motion pursuant to 28 U.S.C. §§ 157(b)(1) and
                  1334(a). This is a core proceeding pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 157(b)(2)(A), (N) and (O). Venue is proper in this District
                  and in the Court pursuant to 28 U.S.C. §§ 1408 and 1409.
                  B. This order constitutes a final and appealable order within the meaning of 28 U.S.C. § 158(a). Notwithstanding
                  Bankruptcy Rules 6004(h) and 6006(d), and to any extent necessary under Bankruptcy Rule 9014 and Rule 54(b)
                  of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, as made applicable by Bankruptcy Rule 7054, the Court expressly finds
                  that there is no just reason for delay in the implementation of this order, and expressly directs entry of judgment as
                  set forth herein.
                  C. The statutory predicates for the relief requested in the Sale Motion are sections 105(a), 363(b), (f), and (m), and
                  365 of the Bankruptcy Code and Bankruptcy Rules 2002(a)(2), 6004(a), (b), (c), (e), (f) and (h), 6006(a), (c) and (d),
                  9007 and 9014.
                  1 Sellers to use commercially reasonable means to obtain copy of Facility Rental Agreement after the signing of the Agreement.
                  Seller will provide such copy to Purchaser.
                  
                  
                  D. The Court entered the Bidding Procedures Order on    , 2007 [Docket No.    ].
                  E. The findings of fact and conclusions of law set forth herein constitute the Court's findings  [*354] of fact and
                  conclusions of law pursuant to Bankruptcy Rule 7052, made applicable to this proceeding pursuant to Bankruptcy
                  Rule 9014.
                  F. To the extent any of the following findings of fact constitute conclusions of law, they are hereby adopted as such.
                  To the extent any of the following conclusions of law constitute findings of fact, they are hereby adopted as such.
                  Any findings of fact or conclusions of law stated by the Court on the record at the Sale Hearing are hereby
                  incorporated, to the extent they are not inconsistent herewith.
                  G. In the absence of a stay pending appeal, the Prevailing Bidder will be acting in good faith pursuant to section
                  363(m) of the Bankruptcy Code in closing the transaction contemplated by the Final APA at any time on or after
                  entry of this Sale Order, and cause has been shown as to why this Sale Order should not be subject to the stay
                  provided by Bankruptcy Rules 6004(g) and 6006(d).
                  II. Notice of the Sale, Auction and the Core Amounts
                  A. Actual written notice of the Sale Hearing, the Auction, the Sale Motion, the Sale, the assumption, assignment
                  and sale of the Executory Contracts and a reasonable opportunity to object or be heard with respect to the Sale
                  [*355] Motion and the relief requested therein has been afforded to all known interested persons and entities,
                  including, but not limited to the following parties (the "Notice Parties"):
                  1. the United States Trustee;
                  2. counsel to the Creditors' Committee;
                  3. counsel to the agent for the Debtors' postpetition secured lenders;
                  4. counsel to the agent to the Debtors' prepetition second lien secured lenders;
                  5. counsel to the agent for the Debtors' prepetition first lien lenders;
                  6. counsel to the ad hoc committee of certain of the Debtors' prepetition second lien secured lenders;
                  7. the Securities and Exchange Commission;
                  8. all taxing authorities having jurisdiction over any of me Sale Assets, including the Internal Revenue Service;
                  9. the United States Department of Justice;
                  10. each of (a) the United States Environmental Protection Agency, (b) the California Department of
                  Conservation; (c) the California Department of Toxic Substances; (d) the California Department of Water
                  Resources; (e) the California Environmental Protection Agency; (f) the California Integrated Waste
                  Management Board; (g) the Indiana Department of Natural Resources; (h) the Indiana Department of
                  Environmental Management; (i) the  [*356] Iowa Department of Natural Resources; (j) the Ohio Air Quality
                  Development Authority; (k) the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency; (l) the Pennsylvania Department of
                  Conservation and Natural Resources; (m) the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection; (n) the
                  Tennessee Department of Environment and Conservation; and (o) the Utah Department of Environmental
                  Quality (the "Environmental Agencies");
                  11. all parties that have requested special notice pursuant to Bankruptcy Rule 2002;
                  12. all persons or entities known to the Debtors that have or have asserted a lien on, or security interest in, all
                  or any portion of the Sale Assets;
                  13. all non-Debtor parties to each Executory Contract and unexpired lease that the Debtors propose to assume
                  and assign to the Prevailing Bidder (each a "Contract CounterParty");
                  14. counsel to the Prevailing Bidder;
                  15. counsel to Atwood Acquisition Co., LLC (the "Stalking Horse Bidder");
                  16. counsel to     (the "Backup Bidder"); and
                  
                  
                  17. all potential bidders previously identified or otherwise known to the Debtors.
                  B. The Debtors published notice of the Sale Motion, the Sale, the time and place of the proposed Auction, the time
                  and place of the Sale Hearing  [*357] and the time for filing an objection to the Sale Motion in the National Edition of
                  the Wall Street Journal, Detroit Free Press, Automotive News and the South Bend Tribune on    , 2007.
                  C. The Debtors have provided sufficient opportunity for the Environmental Agencies to request and review copies of
                  all environmental reports set forth in AP A Schedule 5.11.
                  D. In accordance with the provisions of the Bidding Procedures Order, the Debtors have served notice (the "Cure
                  Notice") upon Prevailing Bidder and the Contract CounterParties: (i) that the Debtors seek to assume and assign

                  E. The Debtors have articulated good and sufficient reasons for the Court to grant the relief requested in the Motion

                  determination of final cure amount; and (iii) approval and authorization to serve the Final Sale Notice (as defined in

                  F. The Debtors' Final Sale Notice provided all interested parties with timely and proper notice of the Sale, Sale

                  G. The Cure Notice provided Prevailing Bidder and the Contract CounterParties with proper notice of the potential
                  assumption and assignment of the Executory Contracts and any cure amount relating thereto, and the procedures

                  H. As evidenced by the affidavits of service previously filed with the Court, proper, timely, adequate, and sufficient
                  notice of the Sale Motion, Auction, Sale Hearing, and Sale has been provided in accordance with sections 102(1),

                  Procedures Order. The notices described in paragraphs A to G above were good, sufficient  [*359] and appropriate
                  under the circumstances, and no other or further notice of the Sale Motion, Auction, Sale Hearing, Sale, or
                  assumption, assignment and sale of the Executory Contracts is required.
                  I. The disclosures made by the Debtors concerning the Sale Motion, APA, Auction, Sale, and Sale Hearing,
                  including but not limited to the Affidavit of Alexander Tracy of Miller Buckfire & Co., LLC in Support of the Debtors'
                  Motion for an Order (a) Approving the Bidding Procedures, (b) Approving the Form and Manner of Notice of the
                  Auction and Sale, (c) Approving Procedures for Determining Cure Amounts in Connection with the Assumption and
                  Assignment of the Executory Contracts, (d) Approving the Assumption of the Executory Contracts, and (e)
                  Approving the Sale of the Sale Assets (the "Affidavit") and the Supplemental Affidavit of Alexander Tracy of Miller
                  Buckfire & Co., LLC in Support of the Debtors' Motion for an Order (a) Approving the Bidding Procedures, (b)
                  Approving the Form and Manner of Notice of the Auction and Sale, (c) Approving Procedures for Determining Cure
                  Amounts in Connection with the Assumption and Assignment of the Executory Contracts, (d) Approving the
                  Assumption of the Executory  [*360] Contracts as Amended, and (e) Approving the Sale of the Sale Assets (the
                  "Supplemental Affidavit"), were good, complete and adequate.
                  III. Good Faith of Prevailing Bidder
                  A. The prevailing bidder(s) for the purchase of the Sale Assets (the "Prevailing Bidder") is not an "insider" of the
                  Debtors, as that term is defined in section 101(31) of the Bankruptcy Code.
                  
                  
                  B. Prevailing Bidder is purchasing the Sale Assets in good faith and is a good faith buyer within the meaning of
                  section 363(m) of the Bankruptcy Code, and is therefore entitled to the full protection of that provision, and
                  otherwise has proceeded in good faith in all respects in connection with this proceeding in that, inter alia: (a)
                  Prevailing Bidder recognized that the Debtors were free to deal with any other party interested in acquiring the Sale
                  Assets; (b) Prevailing Bidder complied with the provisions in the Bidding Procedures Order; (c) Prevailing Bidder
                  agreed to subject its bid to the competitive bidding procedures set forth in the Bidding Procedures Order; (d)
                  Prevailing Bidder in no way induced or caused the chapter 11 filing by the Debtors or any other Debtors; (e) all
                  payments to be made by the Prevailing Bidder  [*361] and other agreements or arrangements entered into by the
                  Prevailing Bidder in connection with the Sale have been disclosed; (f) Prevailing Bidder has not violated section
                  363(n) of the Bankruptcy Code by any action or inaction; (g) no common identity of directors or controlling
                  stockholders exists between the Prevailing Bidder and any of the Debtors; and (h) the negotiation and execution of
                  the final purchase agreement ("Final APA," which is attached hereto as Exhibit A, and which is based upon the
                  APA attached to the Motion, but incorporates changes brought about by the competitive nature of the Auction) and
                  any other agreements or instruments related thereto were at arms' length and in good faith.
                  IV. Highest or best Offer
                  A. Prior to selecting Atwood Acquisition Co., LLC as the stalking horse bidder, the Debtors solicited offers to acquire
                  the Sale Assets from a wide variety of parties. In addition to such solicitations, as set forth in the Supplemental
                  Affidavit, the Debtors also conducted an auction in accordance with the provisions of the Bidding Procedures Order.
                  This auction, which was conducted in compliance with the process set forth in the Bidding Procedures Order,
                  afforded  [*362] a full, fair and reasonable opportunity for any person or entity to make a higher or otherwise better
                  offer to purchase the Sale Assets. The Auction was duly noticed and conducted in a noncollusive, fair and good
                  faith manner and a reasonable opportunity has been given to any interested party to make a higher and better offer
                  for the Sale Assets.
                  B. The Final APA constitutes the highest or best offer for the Sale Assets, and will provide a greater recovery for the
                  Debtors' estate than would be provided by any other available alternative. The Debtors' determination that the Final
                  APA constitutes fee highest or best offer for the Sale Assets constitutes a valid and sound exercise of the Debtors'
                  business judgment.
                  C. The Final APA represents a fair and reasonable offer to purchase the Sale Assets under the circumstances of
                  these chapter 11 cases. No other person or entity or group of entities has offered to purchase the Sale Assets for
                  greater economic value to the Debtors' estate than the Prevailing Bidder.
                  D. Approval of the Sale Motion and the Final APA and the consummation of the transactions contemplated thereby
                  is in the best interests of the Debtors, its creditors, its estate and  [*363] other parties in interest.
                  E. The Debtors have demonstrated compelling circumstances and a good, sufficient, and sound business purpose
                  and justification for the Sale prior to, and outside of, a plan of reorganization.
                  V. No Fraudulent Transfer
                  A. The consideration provided by the Prevailing Bidder pursuant to the Final APA is fair and adequate and
                  constitutes reasonably equivalent value and fair consideration under the Bankruptcy Code and under the laws of
                  the United States, any state, territory, possession, or the District of Columbia.
                  VI. Validity of Transfer
                  A. The Debtors have full corporate power and authority to execute and deliver the Final APA and all other
                  documents contemplated thereby, and no further consents or approvals are required for die Debtors to
                  consummate the transactions contemplated by the Final APA, except as otherwise set forth in the Final APA.
                  
                  
                  B. The transfer of each of the Sale Assets to the Prevailing Bidder will be as of me Closing Date a legal, valid, and
                  effective transfer of such assets, and vests or will vest the Prevailing Bidder with all right, title, and interest of the
                  Debtors to the Sale Assets free and clear of all liens (and Claims (as defined below)  [*364] (collectively, "Liens"))
                  accruing, arising or relating to any time prior to the Closing Date, except for any permitted liens and assumed
                  liabilities (the "Assumed Liens" and "Assumed Liabilities") under the Final APA.
                  VII. Section 363(f) Is Satisfied
                  A. The Prevailing Bidder would not have entered into the Final APA and would not consummate the transactions
                  contemplated thereby (by paying the Purchase Price and assuming the Assumed Liabilities) if the sale of the Sale
                  Assets to the Prevailing Bidder, and the assumption, assignment and sale of the Executory Contracts to the
                  Prevailing Bidder, were not, except as otherwise provided in the Final APA with respect to the Assumed Liabilities
                  and Permitted Liens, free and clear of all Liens and Claims (as defined below) of any kind or nature whatsoever, or
                  if the Prevailing Bidder would, or in the future could (except and only to the extent expressly provided in the Final
                  APA and with respect to the Assumed Liabilities and the Permitted Liens), be liable for any of such Liens or Claims,
                  including, but not limited to, Liens or Claims in respect of the following: (1) any labor agreements; (2) all mortgages,
                  deeds of trust and security interests;  [*365] (3) any pension, welfare, compensation or other employee benefit
                  plans, agreements, practices and programs, including, without limitation, any pension plan of any Debtor; (4) any
                  other employee, worker's compensation, occupational disease or unemployment or temporary disability related
                  claim, including, without limitation, claims that might otherwise arise under or pursuant to (a) the Employee
                  Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, as amended, (b) the Fair Labor Standards Act, (c) Title VII of the Civil
                  Rights Act of 1964, (d) the Federal Rehabilitation Act of 1973, (e) the National Labor Relations Act, (f) the Worker
                  Adjustment and Retraining Act of 1988, (g) the Age Discrimination and Employee Act of 1967 and Age
                  Discrimination in Employment Act, as amended, (h) the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, (i) the Consolidated
                  Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985, (j) state discrimination laws, (k) state unemployment compensation
                  laws or any other similar state laws, or (l) any other state or federal benefits or claims relating to any employment
                  with any of the Debtors or any of their respective predecessors; (5) any bulk sales or similar law; (6) any tax
                  statutes or ordinances,  [*366] including, without limitation, the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended; (7)
                  any Environmental Law(s) (as defined in the Final APA), including, without limitation, any environmental Liens or
                  Claims arising out of, or related to, the reports referenced in APA Schedule 5.11; and (8) any theories of successor
                  liability.
                  B. The Debtors may sell the Sale Assets free and clear of all Liens and Claims against the Debtors, its estate or any
                  of the Sale Assets (except for any Permitted Liens and Assumed Liabilities under the Final APA) because, in each
                  case, one or more of the standards set forth in section 363(f)(1)-(5) of the Bankruptcy Code has been satisfied.
                  Those holders of liens or Claims against the Debtors, its estate or any of the Sale Assets who did not object, or who
                  withdrew their objections, to the Sale or the Sale Motion are deemed to have consented pursuant to section
                  363(f)(2) of the Bankruptcy Code. Those holders of such Liens or Claims who did object fall within one or more of
                  the other subsections of section 363(f) and are adequately protected by having their Liens and/or Claims, if any, in
                  each instance against the Debtors, its estate or any of the Sale Assets, attach  [*367] to the cash proceeds of the
                  Sale ultimately attributable to the Sale Assets in which such creditor alleges an interest, in the same order of
                  priority, with the same validity, force and effect that such creditor had prior to the Sale, subject to any claims and
                  defenses the Debtors and its estate may possess with respect thereto.
                  VIII. Assumption and Assignment of the Executory Contracts
                  A. The assumption and assignment of the Executory Contracts pursuant to the terms of this order is integral to the
                  Final APA and is in the best interests of the Debtors and its estate, creditors and other parties in interest, and
                  represents the reasonable exercise of sound and prudent business judgment by the Debtors.
                  
                  
                  B. The amount set forth on Exhibit B annexed hereto are the sole amounts necessary under sections 365(b)(1)(A)
                  and (B) and 365(f)(2)(A) of the Bankruptcy Code to cure all monetary defaults and pay all actual pecuniary losses
                  under the Executory Contracts (the "Cure Amounts").
                  C. Pursuant to the terms of the Final APA, Prevailing Bidder will: (i) cure and/or provide adequate assurance of cure
                  of any monetary default existing prior to the Closing Date under any of the Executory Contracts, within  [*368] the
                  meaning of section 365(b)(1)(A) of the Bankruptcy Code; (ii) provide compensation or adequate assurance of
                  compensation to any party for actual pecuniary loss to such party resulting from a default prior to the Closing Date
                  under any of the Executory Contracts, within the meaning of section 365(b)(1)(B) of the Bankruptcy Code; and (iii)
                  provide adequate assurance of its future performance under the relevant Executory Contracts within the meaning of
                  sections 365(b)(1)(C), 365(b)(3) (to the extent applicable) and 365(f)(2)(B) of the Bankruptcy Code.
                  IX. Compelling Circumstances for an Immediate Sale
                  A. To enhance the Debtors' level of liquidity, to reduce the amount of postpetition debtor-in-possession financing
                  borne by the Debtors, and to maximize the amount of funding available to provide for a timely exit from these
                  chapter 11 cases, it is essential that the Sale of the Assets occur within the time constraints set forth in the Final
                  APA. Time is of the essence in consummating the Sale.
                  B. Given all of the circumstances of these chapter 11 cases and the adequacy and fair value of the purchase price
                  under the Final APA, the proposed Sale of the Sale Assets to Prevailing Bidder constitutes  [*369] a reasonable
                  and sound exercise of the Debtors' business judgment and should be approved.
                  C. The consummation of the transaction is legal, valid and properly authorized under all applicable provisions of the
                  Bankruptcy Code, including, without limitation, sections 105(a), 363(b), 363(f), 363(m), 365(b) and 365(f), and all of
                  the applicable requirements of such sections have been complied with in respect of the transaction.
                  X. Use of Sale Proceeds
                  A. The Debtors shall use a portion of the Sale Proceeds to pay the Stalking Horse Bidder a Breakup Fee and
                  Expense Reimbursement. The Stalking Horse Bidder's willingness to provide a minimum floor bid and asset
                  purchase agreement facilitated the Auction process and promoted competitive bidding, leading to the highest or
                  best offer from the Prevailing Bidder. Without the Stalking Horse Bidder's initial bid, the Debtors may never have
                  obtained the favorable terms of the Final APA from the Prevailing Bidder. Payment of the Breakup Fee and
                  Expense Reimbursement is therefore appropriate pursuant to section 363 of the Bankruptcy Code.
                  B. The  [*370] Debtors shall also use a portion of the Sale Proceeds to pay down their postpetttion debtor-in-
                  possession financing.

                  7. Pursuant to sections 105(a), 363(b), 363(f), 365(b) and 365(f) of the Bankruptcy Code, the Debtors are

                  8. Except as expressly provided by the Final APA with respect to Permitted Liens and Assumed Liabilities, all

                  Claims on the Sale Assets, if any, as provided for herein, as such Liens or Claims may have been recorded or may

                  9. All persons and entities are hereby forever prohibited and enjoined from taking any action that would adversely

                  Executory Contracts

                  16. Upon the Closing and the Debtors' payment of the relevant Cure Amounts, if any, the Prevailing Bidder shall be

                  constitute valid and valuable consideration for the releases of any potential claims of successor liability of the

                  22. The transactions contemplated by the Final APA are undertaken by the Prevailing Bidder without collusion and
                  in good faith, as that term is defined in section 363(m) of the Bankruptcy Code, and accordingly, the reversal or
                  modification on appeal of the authorization provided herein to consummate the Sale shall not affect the validity of
                  the Sale (including the assumption and assignment of the Executory Contracts), unless such authorization and such
                  Sale are duly stayed pending such appeal. The Prevailing Bidder is a good faith buyer within the meaning of section
                  363(m) of the Bankruptcy Code and, as such, is entitled to the full protections of section 363(m) of the Bankruptcy
                  Code.
                  23.  [*383] Nothing contained in any plan of reorganization or liquidation, or order of any type or kind entered in (i)
                  these chapter 11 cases, (ii) any subsequent chapter 7 case into which any such chapter 11 case may be converted,
                  or (ii) any related proceeding subsequent to entry of this order, shall conflict with or derogate from the provisions of
                  the Final APA or the terms of this order.
                  24. Pursuant to Bankruptcy Rules 7062, 9014, 6004(h) and 6006(d), this order shall be effective immediately upon
                  entry and the Debtors and Prevailing Bidder are authorized to close the Sale immediately upon entry of this order.
                  25. As provided in the Final APA, this order approves and provides for the transfer to Prevailing Bidder of all
                  avoidance claims (whether under chapter 5 of the Bankruptcy Code or otherwise) of the Debtors' estates related to,
                  or arising from, any Assumed Contract or any Assumed Lease or relating to any Assumed Liability.
                  26. No bulk sales law or any similar law of any state or other jurisdiction applies in any way to the Sale.
                  27. There are no brokers involved in consummating the Sale and no brokers' commissions are due.
                  28. The failure specifically to include any particular provision  [*384] of the Final APA in this order shall not diminish
                  or impair the effectiveness of such provision, it being the intent of the Court that the Final APA be authorized and
                  approved in its entirety.
                  29. The Final APA and any related agreements, documents or other instruments may be modified, amended or
                  supplemented by the parties thereto and in accordance with the terms thereof, without further order of the Court,
                  provided that any such modification, amendment or supplement does not have a material adverse effect on the
                  Debtors' estate.
                  30. The Court shall retain jurisdiction to, among other things, interpret, implement, and enforce the terms and
                  provisions of this order and the Final APA, all amendments thereto and any waivers and consents thereunder and
                  each of the agreements executed in connection therewith to which the Debtors are a party or which has been
                  assigned by the Debtors to the Prevailing Bidder, and to adjudicate, if necessary, any and all disputes concerning or
                  relating in any way to the Sale.
                  31. All time periods set forth in this order shall be calculated in accordance with Bankruptcy Rule 9006(a).
                  32. To the extent that this order is inconsistent with any prior order or pleading  [*385] with respect to the Sale
                  Motion in these chapter 11 cases, the terms of this order shall govern.

                  SO ORDERED:

                  TRANSITION SERVICES AGREEMENT
                  This TRANSITION SERVICES AGREEMENT (the "Agreement") is made as of the     day of July, 2007, by and
                  between [DURA OPERATING CORP.], a Delaware corporation, ("Dura"), and [   ], a     ("Purchaser").
                  BACKGROUND
                  WHEREAS, Atwood Mobile Products, Inc., an Illinois corporation and direct wholly-owned subsidiary of Dura
                  ("Atwood") and certain Selling Affiliates of Atwood (together with Atwood, the "Sellers") on the one hand, and
                  Purchaser, on the other hand, have entered into a certain Asset Purchase Agreement dated July 3, 2007 (the
                  "APA"), pursuant to which Sellers agreed to sell, transfer and assign to Purchaser certain assets and liabilities to
                  the extent used in or connected with the Business, pursuant to sections 363 and 365 of the Bankruptcy Code;
                  WHEREAS, the Closing is occurring on me date hereof;
                  WHEREAS, Dura has, up to the date of the Closing, been performing certain corporate and  [*386] administrative
                  services for the Business;
                  WHEREAS, Dura uses certain of the facilities to be transferred to Purchaser pursuant to the APA (the "Transferred
                  Facilities") for activities unrelated to the Business;
                  WHEREAS, following the Closing, Purchaser wishes to receive from Dura certain services of the same quality
                  which Dura provided to the Business prior to Closing, and Dura is willing to provide such services to Purchaser for a
                  limited period, all subject to the terms and conditions hereof; and
                  WHEREAS, following the Closing, Dura desires to lease space in the Transferred Facilities for a limited period of
                  time and Purchaser is willing to provide Dura with access to such space.
                  NOW THEREFORE, in consideration of the mutual covenants contained herein, the parties hereto (the "Parties")
                  intending to be legally bound, agree as follows:
                  1. Definitions. Capitalized terms used in this Agreement shall have the same meanings ascribed to them in the
                  APA, unless separately defined herein.
                  2. Transition Services; Payment.
                  a. Following the Closing, Dura shall provide, and Purchaser shall accept and pay for, those transition services
                  which are specified in Exhibits A through G (each a "Dura Service"  [*387] and collectively, the "Dura
                  Services") attached hereto and made a part hereof. Purchaser agrees to be bound by any additional
                  conditions, covenants and obligations for a specific Service as set forth in the relevant Exhibit describing such
                  Service.
                  
                  
                  Following the Closing, and for a period of nine (9) months, Purchaser shall provide, and Dura shall accept and
                  pay for, office space for certain employees of Dura, the terms of such arrangement are as set forth on Exhibit G
                  hereto (the "Purchaser Services" and collectively with the Dura Services, the "Services").
                  b. Each Service shall be provided for the period specified in the relevant Exhibit describing such Service,
                  provided that such Services provided during the (i) Initial Transition Period shall be provided at cost, (ii)
                  Services provided during the Second Transition Period shall be provided at cost plus 25% and (iii) Services
                  provided during the Third Transition shall be provided at cost plus 50%; provided, however, that the (i) the
                  Purchaser Services set forth on Exhibit G (relating to office space) and (ii) the Dura Services set forth on
                  Exhibit B (Human Resources Shared Services) and Exhibit D (Legal Services) shall be provided at  [*388] cost
                  for the duration of this Agreement and shall not be subject to the step-ups set forth in (ii) and (iii) above. As
                  compensation for the Services, the party receiving the applicable Service (the "Receiving Party") agrees to pay
                  to the party providing the applicable Service (the "Providing Party") the fees for each Service specified in the
                  relevant Exhibit describing such Service. Costs for Services provided by third parties which the Providing Party
                  arranges or incurs on behalf of the Receiving Party ("Pass Through Costs") shall be charged at the direct third-
                  party cost.
                  c. The Providing Party shall invoice the Receiving Party at the beginning of each month for the fixed Services
                  to be provided during the succeeding month. In the case of any Services which are to be provided only upon
                  request, such Services shall be itemized and included in a monthly invoice issued following the rendering of the
                  Services. Pass Through Costs shall also be included in the monthly invoice issued following the date on which
                  they were incurred. All such invoices shall be paid within 30 days after receipt by the Receiving Party. Any
                  invoice that is not paid in accordance with the foregoing terms shall  [*389] be subject to a service charge of
                  1.5% for each month or portion thereof that such invoice remains unpaid.
                  d. The term of this Agreement shall commence on the Closing Date and shall continue for an initial period of six
                  (6) months (the "Initial Transition Period") after me Closing Date; provided that the Receiving Party may, by
                  written notice delivered to the Providing Party, request that particular Services provided during the Initial
                  Transition Period be extended as set forth in the table below (the "Initial Transition Period", the "Second
                  Transition Period" and the "Third Transition Period" are collectively referred to as the "Transition Period").
                  Period

                  Notwithstanding anything contained herein to the contrary, any and all such Services provided hereunder may be
                  earlier terminated pursuant to this Section. Any and all of the Services provided by the Providing Party are
                  terminable earlier than the termination dates set forth in the Exhibits by the Receiving Party upon thirty (30) days'
                  prior written notice to the Providing Party. For termination  [*390] of Services which occur other than month-end (or
                  the applicable billing cut-off date), the Receiving Party shall pay the pro-rated fees through the date such Services
                  were ceased.
                  e. With respect to the aggregate fee for bundled Dura Services provided hereunder as set forth in the Exhibits
                  hereto, Dura shall reduce the aggregate blended fee, on a proportionate basis, to the extent such Dura Service is
                  terminated early by Purchaser.
                  f. Dura shall use commercially reasonable efforts to provide such assistance as Purchaser may reasonably request
                  to assist Purchaser in transitioning the Dura Services in-house such that Purchaser no longer must rely on Dura to
                  perform the Dura Services hereunder; provided, however, that Dura shall not be obligated to expend any out of
                  pocket costs for expenses to third parties associated with providing such assistance.
                  3. [Reserved.]
                  4. Representations and Warranties; Liability.
                  
                  
                  a. Dura shall use reasonable efforts to ensure that all Dura Services are of a quality that is consistent with the
                  quality of those comparable services that were rendered to the Business by Dura prior to Closing.
                  Notwithstanding the foregoing, except in the case of Dura's gross negligence  [*391] or willful misconduct,
                  Purchaser's sole remedy for any defects in performance of the Dura Services shall be for Dura to correct any
                  such defects, where reasonably possible, whether the defects are caused by Dura's breach of the foregoing
                  warranty or negligence. In addition, except in the case of Purchaser's gross negligence or willful misconduct,
                  Dura's sole remedy for any defects in performance of the Purchaser Services shall be for Purchaser to correct
                  any such defects, where reasonably possible.
                  b. Except as otherwise provided herein, the Providing Party makes no representations or warranties, express
                  or implied, under this Agreement, including, without limitation, any warranty of merchantability or warranty of
                  fitness for a particular purpose as to the Services performed hereunder. Except as otherwise provided herein,
                  and except in the case of the Providing Party's gross negligence or willful misconduct, without limiting the
                  general nature of the foregoing, the Providing Party shall have no liability for any losses (including lost time or
                  data), damages, expenses or costs resulting from delays in providing any Services (including any emergency
                  response services), or any utility  [*392] outages, errors in transmission, unavailability, delays or any other
                  failure of the computer or communications systems or support utilized in the provision of the Services, whether
                  such delays, outages, errors or other failures are caused by the Providing Party's breach of warranty or
                  negligence.
                  c. If the Providing Party is or will be unable to deliver the Services, or any of them, in whole or in part, (whether
                  or not such inability was foreseeable or within the contemplation of either party to this Agreement), the
                  Providing Party shall notify the Receiving Party, in writing, as soon as practicable of such inability and its best
                  assessment of its likely duration and the Providing Party's ability to continue to provide such affected Services
                  at a reduced level during the continuation of such event. In such event, the Providing Party shall make all
                  reasonable efforts to remove such disruption of Services in accordance with its standard operating procedures.
                  In the event that the Providing Party shall be able to supply some continuing level of affected Services during
                  the duration of the event, it shall allocate such affected Services among the Receiving Party and its internal
                  customers  [*393] for such Services on such basis as is fair and reasonable.
                  d. In no event shall the Providing Party be liable for any total or partial failure to deliver Services if such failure
                  is due to any circumstance or event beyond the reasonable control of the Providing Party ("Force Majeure
                  Event"). Further, even in the absence of a Force Majeure Event, except as otherwise provided herein, in no
                  event shall the Providing Party be liable to the Receiving Party in an amount greater than the monthly fee in
                  respect of the Service which is judged to be deficient. In no event shall either Party be liable for any indirect,
                  incidental or consequential damages flowing from any breach of its obligations in this Agreement.
                  e. The Receiving Party shall indemnify, and hold harmless, the Providing Party, its Affiliates, and their
                  respective directors, officers and employees, against all losses which might arise or result from the Receiving
                  Party's use of the Services, including, without limitation, any third party claims resulting from the performance
                  of such Services. Upon written request from the Providing Party, the Receiving Party shall assume the defense
                  of any action or proceeding which is subject to  [*394] indemnification pursuant to the provisions of this
                  paragraph; provided that no such action shall be settled without the prior written consent of the Providing Party,
                  unless the settlement involves only the payment of monetary damages which are solely discharged by the
                  Receiving Party. Notwithstanding the obligations of the Receiving Party pursuant to this Section 4, the
                  Receiving Party shall not be required to indemnify the Providing Party for any claims resulting from the
                  Providing Party's failure to obtain any required consent for Services provided hereunder.
                  5. Confidentiality.
                  a. In the process of providing and receiving the Services or otherwise in connection with this Agreement, a
                  Party may have access to Confidential Information (as hereinafter defined) of the other Party. Without limiting
                  the applicability of any other obligation of confidentiality to which the Parties or their Affiliates may be bound,
                  each Party agrees to keep (and cause its Affiliates to keep) any Confidential Information of the other Party
                  strictly in confidence, not to disclose it to any third party without prior written approval of the other Party and to
                  
                  
                  use it only for the purpose of this Agreement, except  [*395] (a) as required by law, in which case the receiving
                  Party shall notify the other Party prior to disclosing such Confidential Information and shall use its best efforts
                  to obtain a protective order or otherwise prevent or minimize disclosure of such Confidential Information, or (b)
                  with the express prior written approval of the other Party.
                  b. For purposes of this Agreement, "Confidential Information" means any confidential information with respect
                  to, including, without limitation, methods of operation, customers, customer lists, Products, prices, fees, costs,
                  Technology, inventions, trade secrets, know-how, software, marketing methods, plans, personnel, suppliers,
                  competitors, markets or other specialized information or proprietary matters. The obligation of confidentiality set
                  forth in Section 5.a above shall not extend to: (a) information that at the time of disclosure was in the public
                  domain or thereafter comes into the public domain through no fault of the receiving Party; (b) information that
                  was known to the receiving Party prior to disclosure by me disclosing Party as substantiated by dated
                  documentation in the files of the receiving Party; and (c) information that becomes  [*396] known to the
                  receiving Party from a source other than the disclosing Party without breach of this Agreement by the receiving
                  Party and not otherwise in violation of the disclosing Party's rights.
                  6. Independent Contractor. The Providing Party shall be deemed to be an independent contractor of the Receiving
                  Party, and not an employee, agent, partner or joint venture partner of the Receiving Party in the performance of its
                  obligations hereunder. The Receiving Party shall be responsible for payments to third party vendors, subject to any
                  reimbursement of costs as set forth in the Exhibits hereto, as well as compensation and benefits to its personnel
                  assigned to perform the Services hereunder, including, but not limited to, worker's compensation, disability benefits,
                  unemployment insurance and withholding, employment or any other taxes imposed or assessed on such
                  employees.
                  7. Entire Agreement Amendment. This Agreement constitutes the entire Agreement between me Parties concerning
                  the subject matter of this Agreement. It supersedes all previous representations, negotiations, warranties,
                  understandings and agreements in respect of me provision of services by Dura or Purchaser, as applicable,
                  [*397] to the other Party. No modification of this Agreement or waiver of any of its terms or conditions shall be of
                  any force or effect unless made in writing and signed by both Parties hereto. No modification of this Agreement
                  shall be effected by the acknowledgment or acceptance of a purchase order or other standard form of either Party
                  (or Affiliate thereof) or any other document containing terms and conditions at variance with or in addition to those
                  set forth herein, all such varying or additional terms being hereby objected to.
                  8. Waiver. The failure of either Party to require the performance of any term or condition of this Agreement or the
                  waiver by either Party of any breach under this Agreement shall not prevent a subsequent enforcement of such
                  term or condition nor be deemed a waiver of any subsequent breach.
                  9. Governing Law. This Agreement shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the Bankruptcy Code
                  and to the extent not consistent with the Bankruptcy Code, the laws of the State of Delaware applicable to contracts
                  made and performed in such State.
                  10. Notices. All notices and other communications under this Agreement shall be in writing and shall be deemed
                  given (i)  [*398] when delivered personally by hand (with written confirmation of receipt), (ii) when sent by facsimile
                  (with written confirmation of transmission) or (iii) one Business Day following the day sent by overnight courier (with
                  written confirmation of receipt), in each case at the following addresses and facsimile numbers (or to such other
                  address or facsimile number as a party may have specified by notice given to the other party pursuant to this

                  Doe v. Hammond
                  United States District Court for the District of Columbia
                  August 22, 2007, Decided
                  Civil Action No. 07-1496 (JDB)
                  Reporter
                  502 F. Supp. 2d 94 *; 2007 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 61264 **; 2007-2 Trade Cas. (CCH) P75,855
                  JOHN DOE, v. SCOTT D. HAMMOND, Acting Assistant Attorney General Antitrust Division, U.S. Department of
                  Justice, et al., Defendants.
                  Subsequent History: Related proceeding at United States v. Korean Air Lines Co., 505 F. Supp. 2d 91, 2007 U.S.
                  Dist. LEXIS 62231 (D.D.C., Aug. 22, 2007)
                  Core Terms
                  plea agreement, movants, grand jury, carve, co-conspirators, grand jury investigation, employees, disclosure,
                  injunction, unindicted, cooperate, press release, proceedings, provisions, accusations, Antitrust, ongoing,
                  subsidiaries, Intervene
                  LexisNexis® Headnotes
                  Civil Procedure > Remedies > Injunctions > Preliminary & Temporary Injunctions
                  Evidence > Burdens of Proof > Allocation
                  Civil Procedure > Remedies > Injunctions > Temporary Restraining Orders
                  HN1[
                  ]  Injunctions, Preliminary & Temporary Injunctions
                  To prevail on an application for a temporary restraining order or preliminary injunction, a plaintiff must demonstrate
                  (1) a substantial likelihood of success on the merits; (2) that he will suffer irreparable harm absent the relief
                  requested; (3) that other interested parties will not be harmed if the requested relief is granted; and (4) that the
                  public interest supports granting the requested relief. These four factors should be balanced, and a particularly
                  strong showing in one area can justify an injunction even if the showings in other areas are rather weak. However, if
                  a plaintiff has no likelihood of success on the merits, inquiry into the remaining factors is unnecessary, for the
                  injunctive relief must be denied on that ground alone.
                  Criminal Law & Procedure > ... > Grand Juries > Secrecy > General Overview
                  HN2[
                  ]  Grand Juries, Secrecy
                  
                  
                  Fed. R. Crim. P. 6(e)(2) provides that an attorney for the government must not disclose a matter occurring before
                  the grand jury. The phrase "matters occurring before the grand jury" encompasses not only what has occurred and
                  what is occurring, but also what is likely to occur, including the identities of witnesses, the strategy or direction of
                  the investigation and the like.
                  Criminal Law & Procedure > ... > Grand Juries > Secrecy > General Overview
                  HN3[
                  ]  Grand Juries, Secrecy
                  The mere possibility that an individual is a subject of a grand jury investigation -- a matter that is unknown -- does
                  not, under the law of United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, prohibit the government from disclosing
                  his name in other contexts, for disclosure of information that is only coincidentally before the grand jury (i.e, the
                  name of a person of interest) is not prohibited by Fed. R. Crim. P. 6(e) as long as it does not elucidate the inner
                  workings of the grand jury.
                  Antitrust & Trade Law > Sherman Act > Claims
                  Antitrust & Trade Law > ... > Monopolies & Monopolization > Conspiracy to Monopolize > Sherman Act
                  Antitrust & Trade Law > Sherman Act > Scope > Monopolization Offenses
                  HN4[
                  ]  Sherman Act, Claims
                  A conspiracy consisting only of an employer and its employees does not violate § 1 of the Sherman Act, 15
                  U.S.C.S. § 1.
                  Criminal Law & Procedure > ... > Grand Juries > Secrecy > General Overview
                  HN5[
                  ]  Grand Juries, Secrecy
                  The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit has never read Fed. R. Crim. P. 6(e) to require that a veil
                  of secrecy be drawn over all matters occurring in the world that happen to be investigated by a grand jury. The
                  disclosure of information coincidentally before the grand jury which can be revealed in such a manner that its
                  revelation would not elucidate the inner workings of the grand jury is not prohibited. The purposes of R. 6(e), as well
                  as the text of the Rule itself, reflect the need to preserve the secrecy of the grand jury proceedings themselves. It is
                  therefore necessary to differentiate between statements by a prosecutor's office with respect to its own
                  investigation, and statements by a prosecutor's office with respect to a grand jury's investigation, a distinction of the
                  utmost significance upon which several circuits have already remarked. Information actually presented to the grand
                  jury is core R. 6(e) material that is afforded the broadest possible protection from disclosure. Prosecutors'
                  statements about their investigation, however, implicate the Rule only when they directly reveal grand jury matters.
                  Criminal Law & Procedure > ... > Grand Juries > Secrecy > General Overview
                  HN6[
                  ]  Grand Juries, Secrecy
                  A discussion of actions taken by government attorneys or officials -- e.g., a recommendation by the Justice
                  Department attorneys to department officials that an indictment be sought against an individual -- does not reveal
                  
                  
                  any information about matters occurring before the grand jury. Nor does a statement of opinion as to an individual's
                  potential criminal liability violate the dictates of Fed. R. Crim. P. 6(e).
                  Constitutional Law > ... > Fundamental Rights > Procedural Due Process > Scope of Protection
                  HN7[
                  ]  Procedural Due Process, Scope of Protection
                  The Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment protects an individual from governmental accusations of criminal
                  misconduct without providing a proper forum for vindication. Where the state attaches a badge of infamy to the
                  citizen, due process comes into play. The more typical case involves an aggrieved person seeking to expunge an
                  indictment revealing his identity as an unindicted co-conspirator; courts generally have found such disclosures to
                  violate the due process rights of the person revealed. However, due process protection is not limited to accusations
                  against the uncharged in an indictment, but rather extends to other criminal accusations made by a government
                  attorney, including accusations in factual proffers and other court memoranda.

                  sufficient to provide Class Counsel the names and current or last-known mailing addresses of all persons who
                  purchased paper-based self-adhesive labelstock or film-based self-adhesive labelstock, other than Defendant
                  Avery's FasClear and PRIMAX film products and foil and piggyback self-adhesive labelstock, from any Defendant,
                  or any present  [*77] or former parent, subsidiary, or affiliate thereof, at any time during the class period of January
                  1, 1996, to July 25, 2003. The term "person" includes, but is not limited to, individuals, corporations, partnerships,
                  and unincorporated associations, but excludes those persons or entities excluded from the Class definition.
                  8. On or before December 31, 2007, Class Counsel shall propose the method and form of notice to the Class that
                  provides the best notice practicable under the circumstances, consistent with Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(c)(2)(B), including
                  individual notice to all members who can be identified through reasonable effort, and a schedule for providing such
                  notice.
